name: transport, freight train, diesel | transport, freight train | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21494/documentation

This dataset represents the transport of one metric ton.km of freight in India by a diesel locomotive. The dataset represents the entire transport life cycle, including the production and maintenance of the locomotive, production and maintenance of the goods wagons, the transportation of goods and the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track. The scope of this dataset is the operation of the locomotive, which has inputs of locomotive and goods wagon, maintenance (goods wagon and locomotive) and railway track via linking to global datasets, i.e. the infrastructure and maintenance datasets are not Indian-specific.      ;Diesel consumption includes shunting and is calculated from annual diesel fuel use per rail segment (Indian Railways, 2017d). The fuel use for freight only transport is taken directly, while the diesel use for shunting is calculated from total shunting diesel consumption, the percentage of shunting engine kilometres for freight movement (63%) (Indian Railways, 2017e) and the percentage of freight gross tonne.kms moved by diesel locomotives (35%) (Indian Railways, 2017b). The diesel use for freight in mixed loads and other train journeys is calculated from the total diesel use in these rail segments (Indian Railways, 2017d) and the percentage of diesel gross tonne.kms for freight movements (52%) (Indian Railwasy, 2017b). These figures represent all rail freight movements in India. ;Emissions of particulates, nitrogen oxides (NOx) and non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) are calculated using emission factors from EcoTransIT (2016). It is assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards. The partitioning of particulate emissions into size classes is according to Spielmann et al. (2007). Sulphur dioxide (SO2) emissions are calculated from the sulphur content in local diesel and the assumption that all sulphur is emitted as sulphur dioxide. Personal communication with a representative of the Indian Oil Corporation Limited confirmed that all refineries in India produce only BS IV diesel, which has a sulphur content of 50 ppm. All other emissions to air are extrapolated on the basis of diesel consumption from the global dataset ("transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004"), with the global dataset derived from data primarily of Swiss/European orgin, described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). ;Locomotive production and maintenance are described in the individual global datasets. Locomotive demand per metric ton.km is calculated from the number of diesel locomotives (Indian Railways, 2017a), the percentage of diesel gross metric ton.kms for freight movement (52%) (Indian Railways, 2017b) and the total metric ton.kms of freight moved by diesel locomotives annually. A locomotive lifespan of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007). Goods wagon production and maintenance are described in the individual global datasets. Goods wagon demand per metric ton.km is calculated from the number of goods wagons (Indian Railways, 2017a), the percentage of diesel gross metric ton.kms due to freight rail (52%) (Indian Railways, 2017b) and the total metric ton.kms of freight moved annually (Indian Railways, 2017a). A goods wagon lifespan of 40 years is assumed (Spielmann et al., 2007). The construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track is described in the global dataset. Demand for railway track per metric ton.km is calculated from the total length of two-way railway track (Indian Railways, 2017a) and the metric ton.kms of freight moved by diesel and electric locomotives annually (Indian Railways, 2017c).;References:;Indian Railways (2017a) Annual Report Accounts - Statistical Summary 2017. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Annual_Report_Accounts_Eng/Statistical_Summary.pdf     ;Indian Railways (2017b) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 16: Tonne kilometrage pertaining to steam, diesel and electric locomotives for 2015-16 and 2016-17. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/16.pdf; Indian Railways (2017c) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 19. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/19B.pdf;  Indian Railways (2017d) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistics Statement 27. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Facts_Figure/Indian%20Railway%20Annual%20Statistical%20Statements%20Final.pdf.; Indian Railwasy (2017e) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistics Statement 17. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Facts_Figure/Indian%20Railway%20Annual%20Statistical%20Statements%20Final.pdf; ;Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.;                                                       ;EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update

The scope of this dataset is the operation of the locomotive and wagon train, with inputs of locomotives, goods wagons and railway track (covering their production, maintenance and disposal). The transportation service starts with the demand for diesel and the construction of locomotive, goods wagons and track. 

The dataset ends with the service of transporting freight 1 metric ton.km. The dataset covers the operation of a diesel locomotive, and includes the consumption of diesel and the associated emissions to air. The dataset calls global datasets on the production and maintenance of a locomotive and goods wagon, as well as the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of railway track.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Demand for diesel, locomotive, goods wagon and railway track from Indian rail transport statistics. Particulate, NOx, SOx and NMVOC emissions from EcoTransIT (2016) applying the emission factors most relevant to Indian locomotives (non-regulated). All other emissions to air extrapolated from global dataset based on diesel consumption.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data is representative of national freight rail for the 2016/2017 financial year
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Emissions to air (other than particulates, NOx, SOx and NMVOC) extrapolated from global dataset on the basis of diesel consumption.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Demand for diesel, locomotive, goods wagon and railway track from Indian national rail transport statistics and representative of all rail freight movements in the reference year. Particulate, NOx, SOx and NMVOC emissions from EcoTransIT (2016) applying the emission factors most relevant to Indian locomotives (non-regulated).

flow.name: transport, freight train
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

exchanges.description: Particulate emissions are calculated from emission factors for non-regulated locomotives (US-EPA emission standards) in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It was assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards. The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update.

Diesel consumption for freight movement and shunting of diesel locomotives is calculated from fuel use per segment in India (Indian Railways, 2017d). The fuel use for freight only transport is taken directly, while the diesel use for shunting is calculated from total shunting diesel consumption, the percentage of shunting engine kilometres for freight operations (63% on broad gauge railways, which account for over 99% of all Indian engine kilometres) (Indian Railways, 2017e) and the percentage of freight gross tonne.kms by diesel locomotives (35%) (Indian Railways, 2017b). The diesel use for freight in mixed loads and other train journeys is calculated from the total diesel use in these segments and the percentage of diesel gross tonne.kms for freight movements (52%) (Indian Railways, 2017b). This is divided by total diesel freight tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c). A diesel density of 0.835 kg/L is assumed (Transport Policy, 2017).                                                                                                                                                                      References: Indian Railways (2017a) Annual Report Accounts - Statistical Summary 2017. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railway board/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Annual_Report_Accounts_Eng/Statistical_Summary.pdf; Indian Railways (2017b) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 16: Tonne kilometrage pertaining to steam, diesel and electric locomotives for 2015-16 and 2016-17. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railway board/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/16.pdf; Indian Railways (2017c) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 19. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/19B.pdf; Indian Railways (2017d) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistics Statement 27. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Facts_Figure/Indian%20Railway%20Annual%20Statistical%20Statements%20Final.pdf.; Indian Railwasy (2017e) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistics Statement 17. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Facts_Figure/Indian%20Railway%20Annual%20Statistical%20Statements%20Final.pdf;                                                                 Transport Policy (2017) India: Fuels: Diesel and Gasoline, Available at: https://www.transportpolicy.net/standard/india-fuels-diesel-and-gasoline/ (23 May 2018).;

exchanges.description:
Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Calculated value for the demand of a locomotive to fulfil one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the number of diesel locomotives used for freight transport and the total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The number of diesel locomotives used is calculated from the total number of diesel locomotives (Indian Railways, 2017a) and the percentage of diesel gross tonne.kms due to freight movement  (52%) (Indian Railways, 2017b).  The tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives is calculated from total diesel freight tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c), with the diesel freight tonne.kms for shunting of electric locomotivs subtracted.  Shunting tonne.kms for electric locomotives is calculated from total diesel shunting tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c) and the percentage of freight tonne.kms by electric locomotives (64%) (Indian Railways, 2017c). 
References:  Indian Railways (2017a) Annual Report Accounts - Statistical Summary 2017. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railway board/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/Annual_Report_Accounts_Eng/Statistical_Summary.pdf;                                                                                              Indian Railways (2017b) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 16: Tonne kilometrage pertaining to steam, diesel and electric locomotives for 2015-16 and 2016-17. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railway board/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/16.pdf; Indian Railways (2017c) Integrated Report 2016/2017 - Statistical Statement 19. Indian Railways. Available at: http://www.indianrailways.gov.in/railwayboard/uploads/directorate/stat_econ/IRSP_2016-17/IR_Statistical_Statements_BI/19B.pdf;                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

exchanges.description: Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Sulphur dioxide emissions are calculated from diesel usage and the assumption that all sulphur in the fuel is converted to sulphur dioxide (Spielmann et al., 2007). India currently uses diesel with a sulphur content of 50 ppm, resulting in an emission index of 1 g/kg.
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Particulate emissions from both abrasion and fuel combustion are considered.  Particulate emissions from the abrasion of railway tracks, wheels, brakes and overhead lines (1.63E-5) are taken from Spielmann et al. (2007).                                                                                                                                                                                   Particulate emissions from diesel use are calculated from emission factors for non-regulated locomotives (US-EPA emission standards) in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It was assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards. The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                        References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update.

Particulate emissions from both abrasion and fuel combustion are considered.  Particulate emissions from the abrasion of railway tracks, wheels, brakes and overhead lines (1.17E-5) are taken from Spielmann et al. (2007).                                                                                                                                                                                   Particulate emissions from diesel use are calculated from emission factors for non-regulated locomotives (US-EPA emission standards) in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel). It was assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards. The breakdown of particulates into size fractions is based on the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004), with the global dataset derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007). In these datasets the particulate size distribution is assumed to match that of diesel locomotives without particulate filters, as presented by EU-Norm IIIa (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                  x                      References: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland; EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with lead emissions in these datasets are based on literature values from Jungbluth (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

NMVOC emissions are calculated from the hydrocarbon emission factor for non-regulated locomotives (US-EPA emission standards) in EcoTransIT (2016) (g/kg diesel), corrected for methane emissions. It was assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards.  
References: EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with mercury emissions in these datasets are based on a literature value from Jungbluth (Spielmann et al., 2007).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with carbon dioxide emissions in these datasets calculated assuming that all carbon in the fuel is converted to carbon dioxide. The emission index is therefore 3,146 g/kg (Spielmann et al., 2007).   
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

EcoSpold01Location=RER
Calculated value for the demand of a locomotive to fulfil one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the number of diesel locomotives used for freight transport and the total tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The number of diesel locomotives used is calculated from the total number of diesel locomotives (Indian Railways, 2017a) and the percentage of diesel gross tonne.kms due to freight movement  (52%) (Indian Railways, 2017b).  The tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives is calculated from total diesel freight tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c), with the diesel freight tonne.kms for shunting of electric locomotivs subtracted.  Shunting tonne.kms for electric locomotives is calculated from total diesel shunting tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c) and the percentage of freight tonne.kms by electric locomotives (64%) (Indian Railways, 2017c). 
References:  Indian Railways (2017a) Annual Report Accounts - Statistical Summary 2017. Indian Railways. Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with carbon monoxide emissions in these datasets based on a literature study on shunting specific emissions indices. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions. Nitrogen oxide emissions are calculated from  emission factors for non-regulated locomotives (US-EPA emission standards) in EcoTransIT (2016). It was assumed that the non-regulated emission factor best fits Indian freight locomotives as these currently do not have to adhere to any emissions standards. 
References: EcoTransIT (2016) Ecological Transport Information Tool for Worldwide Transports - Methodology and Data Update.

Calculated value for the demand of railway track to fulfil one tonne.km of freight transport. Calculation based on the total two-way railway track length (Indian Railways, 2017a) and the total tonne.kms freight transported by diesel locomotives in the year. The tonne.kms transported by diesel locomotives is calculated from total diesel freight tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c), with the diesel freight tonne.kms for shunting of electric locomotivs subtracted.  Shunting tonne.kms for electric locomotives is calculated from total diesel shunting tonne.kms (Indian Railways, 2017c) and the percentage of freight tonne.kms by electric locomotives (64%) (Indian Railways, 2017c).                                                                                                                                               References:  Indian Railways (2017a) Annual Report Accounts - Statistical Summary 2017. Indian Railways. exchanges.description: Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with iron emissions to soil in these datasets based on annual iron load and the assumption that all non-airborne abrasion emissions are emitted as iron to soil.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with emissions in these datasets based on Swiss heavy goods vehicle emissions in urban traffic conditions.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.

Extrapolated from the global dataset (transport, freight train, diesel, GLO, 2004) using diesel consumption. The global dataset is derived from datasets described in full in Spielmann et al. (2007), with heavy metal emissions in these datasets applying literature values from an EEA document, based on an expert panel review. 
Reference: Spielmann, M., Bauer, C., Dones, R. & Tuchschmid, M. (2007) Transport Services Data v2.0, ecoinvent association, Zurich, Switzerland.
